info.game_comments: (Cheryl: Clues about some of the sweetest '60s sounds from the Motown Historical Museum, next on Jeopardy!.)

(1, 1).clue: It's been said that this country "has but one hero, William Tell, and he is a myth"

(2, 1).clue: If you're frigophobic, you won't like your pease porridge this way

(3, 1).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew in front of Motown Studios in Detroit)  In 1959, with $800 borrowed from his family, he founded Motown, which he dubbed "Hitsville, USA"

(4, 1).clue: With the Mets since 1998, he's been called "The greatest-hitting catcher ever to play the game of baseball"

(5, 1).clue: A very thin pasta, capelli d'angelo means angel this

(1, 2).clue: To tour a port wine lodge in the city of Oporto, you'd have to go to this country

(2, 2).clue: If Mary's lamb had didaskaleinophobia, it would have been too scared to follow her here

(3, 2).clue: On one of his early albums, released in 1963, he was billed as a "12 year old genius"

(4, 2).clue: If you know that he bought a half interest in his father-in-law's brewing co. in 1864, you win the blue ribbon

(5, 2).clue: The bow-tie shaped farfalle gets its name from the Italian word for this insect

(1, 3).clue: This country is credited with giving Buddhism to Asia & what are called Arabic numbers to the West

(2, 3).clue: Georgie Porgie didn't suffer from philemaphobia, a fear of this

(3, 3).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew inside Motown Studios in Detroit)  In this very studio, the Temptations recorded their greatest hits, including this one that begins, "I've got sunshine, on a cloudy day..."

(4, 3).clue: A 1956 car crash cut short the life of this American drip artist

(5, 3).clue: Slender vermicelli is less appetizing when you realize its name is from the Italian for this invertebrate

(6, 3).clue: The spicy yellow condiment assembled for roll call

(1, 4).clue: In 1993 Eritrea formally declared its independence from this country

(2, 4).clue: While Mary, Mary was quite contrary, she didn't seem to have antophobia, a fear of these

(3, 4).clue: The Supremes had the most No. 1 hits of any U.S. group, beginning with this song in 1964: "Baby, baby..."

(4, 4).clue: She made a name for herself during the Revolutionary War by bringing water to thirsty soldiers

(5, 4).clue: Flat & broad, linguini is named for this body part

(1, 5).clue: The Sinhalese make up nearly 75% of this island country's population

(2, 5).clue: As he may have had peniaphobia, a fear of poverty, he was in the counting-house counting all his money

(4, 5).clue: This great Israeli-born violinist was stricken by polio when he was 4

(1, 1).clue: "1963: Yesterday" is danced to music made famous by this group, including "Yesterday"

(2, 1).clue: This "Marvelous" lefty boxer KO'd Thomas Hearns in a classic 3-round brawl

(3, 1).clue: With a B.A. from Cambridge in hand, he headed out to sea to see the world as a naturalist

(4, 1).clue: At one point it was fashionable to say "Gray is the new" this; we don't know what the new gray is

(5, 1).clue: The 1620s comedy "The Spanish Gipsy" took its plot from this Spanish novelist

(1, 2).clue: In 1999 Ballet Pacifica premiered "Moonlight", performed to a sonata by this composer

(2, 2).clue: This lefty seen here hits two-handed on both the forehand & backhand

(3, 2).clue: This fighting group was created in 1831 by Louis Philippe for service outside France

(4, 2).clue: They're the 2 appliances in a sub-zero over-under model

(5, 2).clue: Pierre Corneille's masterworks "Horace" & "Cinna" are set in this city

(1, 3).clue: In a ballet based on Bizet's opera, this hussy of a heroine meets a violent end outside a bullring

(2, 3).clue: This fun-loving Raiders quarterback of the '70s was known as "Snake"

(3, 3).clue: In 1831 Pedro I abdicated his throne in this country to his 5-year-old son & went back to Portugal

(4, 3).clue: It's the 6-letter nickname for a BMW

(6, 3).clue: Boyd Matson hosts this National Geographic television program

(1, 4).clue: The story & the music of the ballet "Revenge" come from this composer's opera "Il Trovatore"

(2, 4).clue: Seen here, he learned to golf lefty by standing opposite his father & imitating Dad's swing

(3, 4).clue: First settled in 1831, it's not true that this Michigan city was acquired from local Indians for 25 cents & a box top

(5, 4).clue: As their name implies, disguises were a usual element in these dramas performed at court
